Award.AwardTitle: Data-at-Risk: Developing a Plan for Preserving Astronomy's Archival Records
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide partial support of a workshop titled, "Data-at-Risk: Developing a Plan for Preserving Astronomy's Archival Records". The goal of the workshop is to bring together the world's experts on non-electronic astronomy archival data where they will develop a Plan of Action that will promote the preservation of irreplaceable data. The PI notes that there are over 3 million glass plates or films currently in archives with over half of that data being stored in North America. These archives contain both imaging and spectroscopic data that extends back roughly 120 years. The archives represent a rich resource for long-term variability studies and offer scientific information that cannot be otherwise obtained.

Unless positive action is undertaken soon most of the data in these archives, particularly those being stored in non-optimal conditions, will simply not survive the next decade. The broader impacts of the proposal are inherent in the preservation of the data archives. The impact of data preservation has the potential to affect all facets of observational astronomy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a two-day intensive workshop devoted to initiating development of a plan to preserve astronomy's rich heritage of archival records, especially the photographic observations. The Workshop was held April 18-19, 2012 at the headquarters of the American Institute of Physics (AIP) in College Park, Maryland. The venue was chosen to be readily accessible from locations across North America, and this apparently contributed to slightly greater attendance than anticipated and to keep the cost as low as possible. 

The first day of the Workshop consisted of a series of in-depth round-table discussions framed around a series of 'Guiding Questions.' The questions were designed to provide necessary background and then to establish the basic features of a plan to preserve the heritage material.

The second day began by dividing the participants into small groups tasked with discussing six specific topics deemed critical in developing the preservation plan. The final session was a culminating general discussion on what the plan should include and on how to proceed with implementing it. Detailed notes of the discussions, decisions and recommendations were kept and circulated after the workshop to the participants. 

The main outcomes of the Workshop was the determination on the general features that the preservation plan should contain. It was agreed that: 

The prime objective of the Plan will be to preserve heritage materials that constitute observational records and their metadata on behalf of the astronomical (or wider) community and to have it in a readily accessible and scientifically useful form in order to enable the production of new science. A secondary objective will be to preserve records that are of historical interest. 

To realize the objectives, the following activities will be the key parts of the Plan:

(a) Identify the items and collections covered by the Plan. Include photographic plates and their essential metadata (log books, etc.) with some consideration of non-photographic data records such as magnetic tapes, strip-charts, punched tape and cards and paper documents. Exclude instruments, documents of purely historical nature, and data routinely archived elsewhere (e.g., by NASA, by the American Association of Variable Star Observers). 

(b) Establish protocols and standards for the preservation of the materials and, where necessary, their conversion to electronic form. Preservation efforts should focus on what is scientifically important. Transformation to electronic form, such as digitization of plates, should be done so that electronic copy is as faithful to the original as can be achieved. 

(c) Develop standardized systems for classification, organization and listings of holdings of archival data. User-friendly web-searchable catalogs will be required for efficient access to archived data. Their preparation and use will require both a central database of repositories and consistent catalog information. 

(d) Make archived data sets accessible to researchers. Modern research not only requires not only that data to be in digital form, but also that they be accessible through the internet. The Plan must address how this eventually can be done.

Implementing the Plan will require (a) establishing priorities for action, (b) identifying appropriate collaborating institutions or organizations, (c) promoting awareness of the value of this effort and (d) attracting the requisite funding. A more formal group is needed to oversee the work on the Plan and putting it into operation.
